definitions: happening continuously over a period of time without stopping or pausing
happening again and again in a regular or frequent way
remaining the same in amount, degree, or value over time
examples: The constant rain made outdoor activities impossible
She needs constant attention to feel secure
His constant complaints annoyed everyone in the office
The machine requires constant maintenance to function properly
The temperature remained constant throughout the experiment
Her love for her children was the one constant

definitions: happening or done most of the time in normal circumstances
conforming to what is typical, expected, or standard for someone or something
examples: She arrived at her usual time this morning
Let's meet at the usual place for lunch
He ordered his usual coffee with extra cream
This isn't your usual quality of work today

definitions: relating to the observation and treatment of patients in medical facilities
showing no emotion or warmth; coldly analytical and detached in manner
examples: The clinical trials showed promising results for the drug
She has extensive clinical experience in pediatric care
His clinical approach to the tragedy upset many people
The room had a clinical atmosphere with white walls

definitions: having a small distance from one side to the other
limited in range, extent, amount, or scope of application
achieved or missed by only a small margin or amount
examples: The narrow street could barely fit one car
She walked down the narrow hallway to her room
He has a narrow understanding of world politics
Their narrow focus prevented them from seeing opportunities
It was a narrow escape from the burning building
She won by a narrow margin of two votes

definitions: relating to a population group with shared cultural traditions, ancestry, or nationality
examples: The city celebrates its ethnic diversity with annual festivals
She enjoys trying different ethnic cuisines from around world

definitions: relating to the actual doing or use of something rather than theory
showing good judgment about everyday matters and being sensible in approach
designed to be useful or suitable for a purpose rather than attractive
examples: She gained practical experience through her internship program
The course includes both theoretical and practical components
He's a practical person who plans everything in advance
Let's find a practical solution to this problem
These shoes are practical for walking long distances
She chose practical furniture that would last years

definitions: relating to or connected with music or its performance
having natural ability or skill in creating or performing music
having a pleasant sound that resembles or suggests music in quality
examples: She plays several musical instruments including piano and guitar
The musical performance lasted for two hours
Their daughter is very musical and sings beautifully
He comes from a musical family of performers
Her laughter had a musical quality to it
The birds created a musical symphony at dawn

definitions: completely different in nature, position, or meaning from something else
situated or placed directly across from something else in position
examples: They have opposite opinions about climate change policy
Love and hate are opposite emotions
She sat in the opposite corner of the room
The store is on the opposite side of street

definitions: causing feelings of awe, wonder, or fear through being impressive or overwhelming
extremely impressive, excellent, or outstanding in quality or performance
examples: The awesome power of the hurricane destroyed entire neighborhoods
We witnessed the awesome beauty of the Grand Canyon
That was an awesome concert with incredible performances
She did an awesome job on the presentation

definitions: relating to Iraq, its people, culture, language, or anything originating from Iraq
examples: The Iraqi government announced new economic reforms yesterday
She studied Iraqi history and culture at university

definitions: serving as the foundation or base upon which something is built
absolutely essential, necessary, or important to the existence or nature of something
examples: Understanding grammar is fundamental to learning any language
These are the fundamental principles of physics
Freedom of speech is a fundamental right in democracy
Good communication is fundamental to any successful relationship

definitions: having the most importance, influence, or success in a particular area
going first or in front to show the way to others
examples: She's a leading expert in climate change research
This is one of the leading causes of heart disease
The leading runners were already halfway through the race
He was leading the group through the forest trail

definitions: impossible or very difficult to believe because of being unlikely or extraordinary
extraordinarily good, great, or large in degree, quality, or amount
examples: His story about alien abduction sounds completely incredible
It's incredible that she survived such a terrible accident
The view from the mountain top was absolutely incredible
She has an incredible talent for playing the violin

definitions: relating to Spain, its people, culture, language, or anything originating from Spain
examples: She's learning Spanish to communicate with her relatives
We enjoyed Spanish tapas at the new restaurant downtown

definitions: relating to or connected with people's race or ethnic background and differences
examples: The company implemented policies to prevent racial discrimination
Racial diversity enriches our community and promotes understanding

definitions: shared, done, or owned by two or more people or groups together
connecting or holding together two or more parts, pieces, or sections
examples: They opened a joint bank account after getting married
The countries issued a joint statement on climate action
The carpenter reinforced the joint between the two boards
She has pain in her knee joint from running

definitions: extremely large in size, quantity, extent, or degree beyond normal proportions
examples: The enormous elephant towered over the safari vehicles
They faced enormous challenges in rebuilding after the hurricane

definitions: worth a considerable amount of money or having high monetary value
extremely useful, helpful, or important in achieving something or to someone
examples: The museum houses many valuable paintings from famous artists
She kept her valuable jewelry in a safe
Your advice has been valuable in helping me decide
Time is our most valuable resource in life

definitions: operating by or producing electricity as a source of power
causing sudden excitement, tension, or anticipation in atmosphere or feeling
examples: She drives an electric car to reduce emissions
The electric lights flickered during the storm
The atmosphere in the stadium was absolutely electric
There was an electric tension between the two rivals

definitions: continuing to exist or be left after other parts have been removed, used, or dealt with
examples: We need to use the remaining ingredients before they expire
The remaining students stayed after class for extra help

definitions: relating to or connected with a congress, especially the United States Congress
examples: The congressional hearing will investigate the security breach
She works as a congressional aide in Washington D.C.

definitions: not guilty of a crime or offense that one is accused of
having no knowledge or experience of something, especially something bad
not intended to cause harm or offense; simple and trusting
examples: The jury found the defendant innocent of all charges
She maintained she was innocent throughout the trial
Children are innocent of the world's harsh realities
He was innocent of any wrongdoing in the scandal
It was just an innocent joke between friends
Her innocent smile melted everyone's heart

definitions: correct in all details and conforming exactly to truth or to a standard
examples: The weather forecast was accurate about the coming storm
She keeps accurate records of all business transactions

definitions: becoming greater in size, amount, number, degree, or intensity over time
examples: There's increasing concern about climate change among young people
The company reported increasing profits for the third quarter

definitions: relating to Arabs, their culture, language, history, or countries in the Arabian region
examples: She studied Arab literature and poetry at university
The museum features a collection of ancient Arab artifacts

definitions: covered or marked with dirt, mud, or unwanted substance
dishonest, unfair, or morally wrong in behavior or methods
containing sexual or offensive language, images, or subject matter
examples: His clothes were dirty after working in the garden
Please wash your dirty hands before eating dinner
The company used dirty tricks to eliminate their competition
That was a dirty move in the game
He told dirty jokes that made everyone uncomfortable
The movie had too many dirty scenes for children

definitions: sudden, very great, and often surprising in effect or degree
relating to drama or the performance of plays and theater
showing excessive emotion or behaving in an exaggerated way for effect
examples: There was a dramatic increase in sales last month
The dramatic rescue was caught on camera
She studied dramatic arts at the performing arts school
The play had dramatic scenes that moved the audience
Stop being so dramatic about a small problem
His dramatic reaction seemed unnecessary for the situation

definitions: having the color that is pale red, between red and white
examples: She wore a pink dress to the spring wedding
The cherry blossoms turned the whole street pink

definitions: unable to find one's way or not knowing one's location
no longer possessed, owned, or found; unable to be recovered
having suffered defeat or having failed to win or succeed
examples: We got lost in the forest without a map
The lost child was crying for his mother
She never recovered her lost wedding ring
All data was lost when the computer crashed
They felt lost after their team was eliminated
It was a lost cause from the beginning

definitions: done in accordance with established rules, conventions, or ceremony
having an official or important quality suitable for serious occasions
very correct and stiff in manner, appearance, or behavior
examples: Please submit a formal request through proper channels
The formal rules of chess must be followed
They attended a formal dinner at the embassy
She wore formal attire to the awards ceremony
His formal manner made everyone feel uncomfortable
The letter was written in very formal language

definitions: of very great size, height, or strength compared to ordinary things
very successful, important, or influential in a particular field
examples: The giant redwood trees can live for thousands of years
A giant wave crashed against the ship
He was a giant in the field of physics
The company became a giant in the tech industry

definitions: with no special or distinctive features; normal, usual, and not remarkable
examples: It was just an ordinary day until the surprise arrived
She preferred ordinary clothes to designer fashion

definitions: used to show skepticism about a term or to indicate the name commonly used
examples: These so-called experts don't really understand the problem
The so-called healthy snacks contained lots of sugar

meanings: giving or ready to give help
definitions: giving or ready to give help, assistance, or support to others
examples: The staff at the hotel were incredibly helpful
Your suggestions have been very helpful in solving this

definitions: involving or characterized by competition between rivals or participants
having a strong desire to win or be more successful than others
as good as or better than others in quality or price
examples: Professional sports are highly competitive environments
The job market has become increasingly competitive
She's very competitive and hates losing any game
His competitive nature drives him to excel
They offer competitive prices on all their products
The salary package is competitive with industry standards

definitions: beautiful, attractive, or appealing in a delicate or graceful way
very pleasant, enjoyable, or delightful in nature or character
examples: She looked lovely in her wedding dress
The garden has lovely flowers blooming in spring
We had a lovely time at the beach
What a lovely surprise to see you here

definitions: relating to Islam, its teachings, culture, history, or followers
examples: She studies Islamic art and architecture at university
The museum has a collection of Islamic manuscripts

definitions: different from what is usual, expected, or normal; strange
of a number that cannot be divided exactly by two
happening or occurring occasionally and not forming a regular pattern
examples: He has some odd habits that puzzle his friends
It's odd that she didn't call to say goodbye
Three, five, and seven are odd numbers
Pick any odd number between one and ten
She does odd jobs to earn extra money
I still have a few odd pieces to finish

definitions: profoundly immoral, wicked, or wrong according to moral principles
causing or likely to cause harm, suffering, or misfortune
examples: The evil dictator oppressed his people for decades
Many fairy tales feature good triumphing over evil
An evil smell came from the abandoned building
The storm brought evil weather that destroyed crops

definitions: feeling or showing happiness and enthusiasm about something that has happened or will happen
examples: The children were excited about going to the amusement park
She was too excited to sleep before her wedding

definitions: deserving condemnation or punishment, especially according to religious beliefs
used to emphasize or express anger, frustration, or annoyance
examples: The preacher spoke of damn souls in hellfire
He feared his damn fate after death
This damn car won't start again this morning
I can't find my damn keys anywhere

definitions: consisting of many interconnecting parts or elements that make something difficult to understand
examples: The instructions for assembling the furniture were very complicated
Their relationship became complicated after the misunderstanding

definitions: unable to see because of injury, disease, or congenital condition
lacking perception, awareness, or judgment about something obvious
not based on reason or evidence; unquestioning
examples: The blind musician played piano beautifully by ear
Guide dogs help blind people navigate safely
He was blind to her obvious feelings for him
Don't be blind to the dangers of smoking
Her blind faith in him proved to be misguided
Blind hatred will only lead to more conflict

definitions: lesser in importance, seriousness, or significance compared to something else
below the age of full legal responsibility, typically under eighteen years
examples: She had minor surgery to remove a small cyst
There were only minor changes to the original plan
Minors cannot vote or sign legal contracts
The store doesn't sell alcohol to minors

definitions: operating through or produced by the flow of electrons in circuits, chips, or devices
examples: Most modern devices have electronic components inside them
She prefers electronic books to traditional paper ones

definitions: judged over time to be of the highest quality and outstanding
having a simple, traditional style that is always fashionable
examples: Pride and Prejudice is a classic novel everyone should read
That movie is a classic example of film noir
She wore a classic black dress to the event
His classic car collection includes several vintage models

definitions: causing feelings of enthusiasm, eagerness, and heightened interest or emotion
examples: The exciting news spread quickly through the office
Planning our trip to Japan is really exciting

definitions: loved, cherished, or regarded with deep affection by someone
charging or costing a high price relative to value
examples: My dear grandmother passed away last year
He wrote a letter beginning with Dear Sarah
Everything in that store is too dear for my budget
The restaurant was good but rather dear

definitions: damaged, separated into pieces, or cracked from being whole
not functioning or working properly as intended or designed
interrupted in continuity, sequence, or pattern; not kept or fulfilled
examples: The broken window needs to be replaced immediately
She swept up the broken glass from the floor
My phone is broken and won't turn on
The broken elevator forced everyone to use stairs
He speaks in broken English with a heavy accent
Their broken promises destroyed the trust between them

definitions: able to be seen by the eye or perceived clearly
examples: The mountains were visible from miles away on clear days
The stain on his shirt was clearly visible
